section_1_sacred_text.original_script: καὶ φωνὴ πάλιν ἐκ δευτέρου πρὸς αὐτόν· Ἃ ὁ θεὸς ἐκαθάρισεν σὺ μὴ κοίνου.
section_1_sacred_text.faithful_direct_translation: And a voice again for a second time to him: What things God has cleansed, you must not make common.
section_1_sacred_text.standalone_english_translation: And the voice came to him again a second time, 'What God has made clean, do not call common.'
section_1_sacred_text.amplified_narrative_translation: Then a voice from heaven spoke directly to him once more, for the second time, with a clear and binding command: The very things which God Himself has pronounced ritually pure and ceremonially clean, you must immediately stop regarding or designating as unholy, profane, or defiled.

section_2_exegetical_synthesis: The literal, primary meaning of the text is a direct, audible command from heaven to the Apostle Peter.
This command explicitly overturns Peter's religiously-conditioned refusal to interact with what he perceives as unclean.
The vision's subject was a great sheet containing animals forbidden for consumption under the Mosaic Law (Acts 10:12-14; cf. Leviticus 11, Deuteronomy 14).
This collection of animals serves as a divinely-appointed 'Type' or living parable representing the Gentile nations.
The Levitical dietary laws were the 'Shadow,' establishing a physical barrier that symbolized Israel's covenantal separation from the Gentile world (Leviticus 20:25-26).
The 'Antitype' or fulfillment is the inclusion of the Gentiles into the one new man in Christ, breaking down this ceremonial wall of separation (Ephesians 2:14-16).

This moment is the Apostolic realization of Christ's own teaching where He had already, in principle, 'declared all foods clean' (Mark 7:19), thereby nullifying the ceremonial basis for separating from people.
It also fulfills the prophetic hope that God's salvation would be a 'light to the Gentiles' (Isaiah 49:6) and that foreigners would be welcomed into His covenant (Isaiah 56:6-7).
The Greek syntax is a divine imperative founded on a divine declaration.
The declaration is, [Ἃ ὁ θεὸς ἐκαθάρισεν] (Ha ho theos ekatharisen, 'What things God has cleansed').
[ἐκαθάρισεν] (ekatharisen) is aorist active indicative, signifying a past, completed, and settled act of cleansing performed by God Himself.
The command is, [σὺ μὴ κοίνου] (su mē koinou, 'you do not make common').
[μὴ κοίνου] (mē koinou) is a present active imperative, meaning 'Stop considering common' or 'Do not persist in the habit of calling unclean.'
The command is personal and emphatic, directed at [σὺ] (su, 'you'), Simon Peter.
His name, Peter, from [Πέτρος] (Petros, 'a rock'), highlights his foundational role, making his acceptance of this truth critical for the Church's mission (Matthew 16:18).
His given name, Simon, from the Hebrew [שִׁמְעוֹן] (Shimon, 'he has heard'), is profoundly significant here, as he is being commanded to truly hear and obey this new word from God.
The primary literary device is repetition; the entire vision and command occurred three times (Acts 10:16).

In Hebrew thought, the number three signifies divine emphasis, certainty, and legally binding witness (Deuteronomy 19:15), leaving Peter with no doubt as to the vision's authority and origin (cf. Genesis 41:32).
The event is dated to approximately AD 40-41.
This chronological context places it after the initial persecution that scattered the church (Acts 8:1) but before the systematic mission to the Gentiles was established.
The historical backdrop is the deeply entrenched social and religious segregation between Jews and Gentiles in the Second Temple Period.
This separation was a cornerstone of Jewish identity, especially in Roman-occupied Judea, making table fellowship with a Gentile a profound transgression for a devout Jew.
The socio-political matrix includes the volatile reign of Roman Emperor Caligula (AD 37-41) and the rising influence of Herod Agrippa I.
Jewish nationalism was simmering, and any perceived compromise with 'unclean' Gentiles could be viewed as both a religious and political betrayal.
This event occurred in the ancient seaport of Joppa (modern Jaffa, a district of Tel Aviv-Yafo, Israel).
Geospatial Data: Approx. Latitude 32.05° N, Longitude 34.75° E; Altitude near sea level.
The setting is the rooftop of the house of 'Simon, a tanner' (Acts 10:6), located 'by the sea'.

The geography of Joppa is theologically significant; it is the very port from which the prophet Jonah fled to avoid his mission to the Gentile city of Nineveh (Jonah 1:3). Peter is now commissioned from the same location *to go* to the Gentiles.
Archaeological context confirms that tanning was considered a ritually 'unclean' profession due to its handling of dead carcasses, making the location itself a preparatory step for Peter.
The fact that Peter, a Galilean fisherman, was already lodging with a tanner demonstrates a prior work of the Spirit in softening his adherence to the strictest interpretations of purity laws.
In the aggregate perspective of Scripture, this verse is the doctrinal hinge upon which the Gentile mission swings open.
It is God's direct authorization for the Gospel to officially cross ethnic and ceremonial boundaries.

Peter's experience here becomes the definitive legal precedent he uses to defend his actions to the Jerusalem council, resulting in their conclusion that 'to the Gentiles also God has granted repentance that leads to life' (Acts 11:18).

This declaration provides the experiential foundation for the theological truths later articulated by Paul, namely that in Christ 'there is neither Jew nor Greek' and Gentiles are 'fellow heirs' (Galatians 3:28, Ephesians 3:6).
Ultimately, the voice from heaven reveals that the categories of 'clean' and 'unclean' are not inherent in things or people, but are designations determined by God's sovereign word alone.
section_3_life_application: The core application is to actively identify and dismantle any personal prejudice, cultural bias, or religious tradition that causes you to label a person or group of people as 'unclean,' 'unworthy,' or 'common.'

Recognize that God's cleansing work through the blood of Christ is definitive and absolute. If God has declared someone clean by calling them to Himself, you have no authority to contradict Him with your own standards.

Therefore, stop avoiding people you have been conditioned to see as 'other.' Intentionally build relationships and share the fellowship of the Gospel with those outside your social, economic, racial, or political circles.

Be obedient to the Holy Spirit's prompting, even when it challenges your deepest-held comforts, traditions, and fears, just as Peter was commanded to do. God's command to 'go' often requires us to first abandon our internal categories of 'don't go.'
